Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Erica Bergen Barth-Naftilan  I didn't have much direct interaction with her, but she always seemed to be on top of it and answered questions when I had any.

Instructor: Erica Bergen Barth-Naftilan  Erica appeared to have read the papers in as much detail as the students. She offered valuable comments during class discussion that helped spur conversation among the student.
Instructor: Erica Bergen Barth-Naftilan  Knowledgeable, helps lead discussion, well prepared
Instructor: Erica Bergen Barth-Naftilan  Great contributions to discussion and lecture. Provided useful examples and lessons from research experience.
Instructor: Erica Bergen Barth-Naftilan  Erica was always willing to make a point or ask a question to steer the conversation in new and thought-provoking directions.
Instructor: Erica Bergen Barth-Naftilan  Erica did a great job of asking thought-provoking questions and helping to share some of the teaching with Jim.
Instructor: Erica Bergen Barth-Naftilan  Very knowledgeable and offered different opinions than Jim - nice to hear different perspectives

Instructor: Erica Bergen Barth-Naftilan  Helpful in lectures-- some time outside of class to cover additional material or discussion would be nice for prep with the presentation aside from the initial meeting with Jim
Instructor: Erica Bergen Barth-Naftilan  Strengths: Erica established a great graduate seminar norm in the course where ideas were discussed with every member of the class coming from equal footing

Instructor: Erica Bergen Barth-Naftilan  Erica, while knowledgable, lacked professionalism. However she was knowledgable on the topics at hand and her insight was overall productive to the course. She was also responsible for tracking participation, though some students noticed that she did not accurately capture comment counts and seemed to miss comments for students whose opinions differed from her own.
Instructor: Erica Bergen Barth-Naftilan  Awesome contributions to class discussions. Very thought provoking. She felt like a member of the class going through the same process as the students.
Instructor: Erica Bergen Barth-Naftilan  Erica really added value to the course. She brought up interesting questions during classes and she has a strong critical thinking
Instructor: Erica Bergen Barth-Naftilan  she was well informed and provided great insights

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This seems to be the only class of its kind at FES - for students interested in any kind of energy, this class can add value to the rest of your coursework.

This course should be mandatory for anyone studying energy and natural resources. The format was a high-level mix of geology, hydrology, and environmental science coupled with student discussion of important topics surrounding the sustainability of the energy industry in the U.S. The instructor is an expert in all, and created a very valuable learning environment by way of the format of the course.
I really enjoyed the class overall. I thought Jim did a good job facilitating conversation.

Dr Saiers is extremely knowledgable on the topics at hand but did not provide adequate insight during discussions. While having a student-led discussion can be helpful, more direct commentary from Dr Saiers would have been better. Additionally, guidelines for the written report were not clear.

Jim is one of the best instructors at FES. Anything he teaches is going to be good. The course material met the real need for Water Resource minded students, and was extremely applicable to jobs and other course materials.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Learning to write executive summaries is a key skill, and I got some practice doing so. I would have liked to have gotten more examples of executive summaries, and spoken a little more about why they are relevant/important and gotten more substantial writing tips for how it can be done better. I also really enjoyed the panels on the last day of class--it really tied everything together.
Being directed to the most recent and relevant research in certain energy issues.
The class discussions were the clear highlight. Jim has a knack for facilitating meaningful discussion.
Student discussion. The assignment where each student was required to facilitate a lecture on a specific topic was extremely valuable.
Jim created a collegial, relaxed learning environment that made students feel comfortable and encouraged thoughtful participation from everyone.

I have not taken many discussion - based classes at F&ES, but I thought this one was excellent. Jim and Erica created an environment that was both relaxed, but also engaging to foster interesting conversations and encourage questions. I don't always participate extensively in class, but I never felt like I was "on the spot" or asking a "stupid question". I learned a lot and enjoyed coming to class each week.
I thought the last class was great.

I enjoyed the survey of various energy types and thought the format of the class was well suited to allow for a variety of topics to be covered, but to also delve in depth into those topics during an individual class. I appreciated the variety of experiences of the students in the class and thought they added a lot to the discussion
The variety of different perspectives, a pursuit of conflict and parsing out the nuances of key issues, and an open environment that enabled rich discussion.
Excellent discussion and participation. The flexibility in scheduling and pace made it really adaptive to the students' needs.
It is a course that fosters the discussion among students. Because there were students with different backgrounds, the discussion level raised in class improved substantially the course's quality.
the classes studies different resource life cycles each week providing a wide scope of knowledge

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The class was a work in progress. Things kept changing, and it might have been helpful to have a better idea of where we were going at the start of the semester (a more flushed-out syllabus, that didn't change so frequently). Also, it seemed like we were trying to tie science and policy together, but the course was not very successful at doing that. I think we would have needed to read more policy documents, especially since most students did not have experience in policy. We often discussed policy implications of the science we read, but without a background in policy, the discussions were uninformed and not very useful. Maybe bring in a guest speaker who works for Pennsylvania's DEP and could explain fracking regulations, challenges to regulation, etc? Something along those lines (for each unit) would be incredibly valuable.

I think the timing of student presentations may need to be adjusted. Sometimes we wouldn't get through all the papers, or would not have enough time for discussion on a particular topic. Discussion could be improved by moving away from granular details and focusing more on big-picture ideas.
no changes needed
At times, it felt as though discussions tracked in circles because no one was really an expert on the topic. Questions would be raised without someone able to answer them.

I know this was the first time this class was offered but it would have been helpful to be able to sign up for our presentation dates and topics in advance. People didn't really have much say in what they presented on or when, which made it difficult to plan/coordinate assignments for other courses.
Sometimes the three hours felt like a long time - when it was hard to get people to talk.
More clarity around the format of presentations and best way to focus executive summaries would be helpful

A little more structure about the lecture needs. Some students didn't have the same material knowledge, which sometimes dragged discussions down a level. Requiring WRM (Shimi) as a pre-req would be good.

The course too US-focused. The course focuses mainly on US problems/challenges and at some extent, China. I would have preferred to learn more about the energy and water nexus in other parts of the world as well and be able to identify the challenges that developing countries face and understand the differences of these challenges to what US has to deal with. The course is graded according to individual participation in class what may favor domestic students since the course is mainly focused on US issues.
The class was well organized and needs little improvement if any

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: very effective, no improvement needed

The course lectures were integral to the discussion. Different presenters each week helped to change it up and keep the conversation going. Asking questions prior to the class was helpful in spurring conversation before class even started.
Discussion sections were good.
The discussion took place during the course's sessions and it was very effective in upgrading the course. There are no extra discussion sessions during the course.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: My interests lie at the intersection of energy and water use.

The class is an interesting introduction into the energy sector. As a "water" person, I don't take many energy classes (there's only so many classes you can take!), but this was an excellent broad sweep into many energy sectors while still tying into my water interests in a new and relevant way.
Helpful look at variety of issues in energy industry and connections to water use-- I think it is an important topic and has encouraged me to take more courses in this area
Meets the crucial need of tying water courses to a pressing industry that dominates the environmental field.
it informs my specialization and introduces me to different perspectives and hard trade offs that need to be made in management

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I was interested in learning more scientific/technical knowledge of how energy development impacts water resources. Definitely got that, but I think it would have helped if Professor Saiers had done a bit more lecturing. For instance, before reading the first papers on coal (at the end of the fracking unit), he could have done a 20 min lecture on coal mining, to give us context and make it easier for us to understand the scientific literature we were delving into.
I wanted to be up to date on current research in energy issues to be informed and equipped for the sometimes controversial conversations that arise in everyday life when discussing energy.

I did not have a background in any of the fields covered in class. My interest is in energy markets. The depth of topics in energy we covered in class was exactly what i needed, and was essential to my understanding of the dynamics at play in energy industry.
See above.
New topic for me. Had not delved into energy sector.
Interested in both water and energy-- great fit
To learn more about hydrology and how energy resources effect the water supply from the water management perspective.
Round out my water resource management knowledge.
I am deeply interested in water scarcity and climate change. The relationship between energy and water is very important to solve water scarcity issues.
It provides my water specialization by introducing me to energy effects on water resources and providing management option expecially for developing countries that are discovering natural resources

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Almost. I got a lot out of the scientific articles, but I think the course fell short in addressing how that information we learned has implications for environmental managers. Most students in the course were not hydrogeologists and are not going on to get PhDs (instead, there are lots of MEMs), so it would have been nice if it could have been better tailored to the students in the class.
Yes, the course met my expectations. I feel like I learned new information about the topics I care most about.
Exceeded my expectations. I was impressed with the professors knowledge of the subjects and topics covered in class.
Yes, although I would have liked a section on water and energy use in building end uses (heating, cooling, hot water heating).
Yes.
Yes, It did. The class was very useful and I learned a lot from it
Mostly, yes.
Yes-- great way to read the literature in the field and become familiar with key challenges and topics
yes
Yes. Absolutely.
The course was really good. Erica and Jim are highly-experienced professionals and students can learn a lot from them.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Minimized the workload, and allowed us to deliver a stronger paper by working together.
The group work was good - we each had our own paper but met a couple times to tie them into eachother.
We were able to learn from each other
Good to have someone to review the material and talk through the presentation with-- i thought working in pairs was a good way to approach the presentations

The course requires to give a presentation about a certain topic that is chosen by Jim and Erica. Each student has to give only one presentation. It was really helpful to share ideas and points of view when working in a group.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's a great class to learn more about what we do and do not know about how energy development impacts water resources, and it helps you develop a more informed opinion on relevant issues. Spend a good amount of time digging into the readings, and you'll get a lot out of the class in terms of scientific knowledge. However, what you learn from the discussions also depends on the other students in class with you, and prior knowledge/experience of other students can really make or break the course.

For those who are passionate about energy and sustainability, this course will either force you to re-evaluate your positions and fundamental understanding of this industry, or it will solidify your convictions. It's a fantastic look at the industry from the academic side.
Get comfortable reading scientific articles.
Do the reading early, so you're not rushing through it on Monday/Tuesday. I felt I had more to contribute when I read papers over the weekend.
It is a recommended class, definitely take it
I thought it was pretty good and worth it if the topic interests you.
take it!
Come prepared for a graduate seminar with a stellar teaching team. I wish that I had been able to engage more in the topic because I barely tapped the depth of their knowledge.
As a WRM student, this was one of the best courses I took at FES.

I would recommend this course to students that are interested in learning about the interlinkages between water and energy specially in the US. If you are an international student, please be aware that the course is majorly US-focused and your contribution to the class may be limited relatively to domestic students. Thus your grade may be capped as well.
it is a good course on the nexus between water and energy production and how the life cycle processes on different energy production resources affect water resources
